title: Greece Defaults As It Fails To Make IMF Payment
text:

Wed, Jul 1, 2015, 02:20 BST - UK Markets open in 5 hrs 40 mins Greece Defaults As It Fails To Make IMF Payment By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 17 minutes ago View Photo 

The deadline for Greece to make a €1.5bn to the International Monetary Fund has formally expired and the country is now in arrears on its international loan. 
Athens defaulted on its debt after eurozone finance ministers rejected a last-minute bid for an extension of Greece's bailout . 
Talks will resume on Wednesday to discuss a new two-year financial aid plan proposed by Greece, which includes a request for debt restructuring. 
"I confirm that the SDR 1.2 billion repayment due by Greece to the IMF today has not been received," said IMF spokesman Gerry Rice said. 
"We have informed our Executive Board that Greece is now in arrears and can only receive IMF financing once the arrears are cleared." 
The expiry of the deadline makes Greece the first developed country to fall into arrears on an IMF payment. 
Thousands of people rallied in Athens before the deadline passed in support of a deal with international creditors. 
At least 20,000 people, many waving European and Greek flags, gathered in front of parliament in Syntagma square five days before a referendum on whether or not to accept a new bailout. 
A No vote could see Greece leave the eurozone. 
Noufris Mastoras, who works at a brewery in Corfu told Sky (Other OTC: BSYBF - news ) 's Siobhan Robbins that negotiations should focus on keeping Greece in the eurozone. 
"Greece is a European Union member and has to stay a European Union member and I think Greece will stay in the EU and euro," he said. 
"Euro makes it easy because all countries have a share of the same currency. If we change back to drachma the cost for Greece will be much larger so we can import things" 
Yannis Kardakis showed Sky News an old drachma note and when asked if he thought Greece may soon be using them again replied: "I think so". 
Despite this, he is still keen to stay in stay in the EU.. 
"All the people in Greece we worry about what's going to happen tomorrow, what's going to happen the next day, the next week, the next month, it's our future. But I believe that Europe can't leave us like that." 
Greek banks have been closed and cash machines withdrawals restricted to €60 a day to prevent the banking system collapsing as default neared. 
Athens has received nearly €240bn in two bailouts from the European Union and International Monetary Fund since 2010, but the Greek people have been forced to accept cuts to pensions, wages and public services.
